review_title: I've had several jobs in my life. This is way more than a job, it is a calling and a gift!

You can see incredible moves of God and immense heartbreak all in the same day. You truly have to be called to this in order to thrive.

review_title: Mostly Great Culture, But Beware of Bad Leaders
pros: Great and important mission, many opportunities for personal growth development, competitive benefits package, casual atmosphere, awesome events and staff appreciation
cons: 1. Sacrifice is a given in ministry, but sometimes that banner is waved to keep people quiet when they have to live with the negative impacts of leaders’ poor decisions. It can feel manipulative. 2. There are several staff who have track records of bulldozing, manipulation, gaslighting, and deceit, and even though their leaders know about it, these staff members are given new opportunities with higher influence and impact. When a leader continues to allow this, the leader is the one to blame. Meanwhile, dozens of faithful, trustworthy, long-tenured staff remain in the trenches, doing fantastic work, but they are actively held back same opportunities for advancement, no matter how deserving they may be. It’s gotten to the point that it seems to be more about who likes a person than how good they are at their job. 3. Those who are not “conventionally attractive” may find it difficult to get outward facing opportunities, regardless of their skills or talent. 4. Even though there are 45 locations, only 2 are led by women, which seems to indicate a gap in leadership development between men and women for those highest campus leadership roles. We can do better!

pros: Got to experience many changed lives and work with some amazing people. Benefits are good.
cons: When I first started attending/working at Life.Church years ago, the mission and the momentum was tangible. The church was reaching people, loving the lost and cared deeply for their staff team. When I look at the state of affairs now, it is not the same church. A few things to be aware of: - In my opinion, there seems to be a culture of spiritual harshness and I would even dare say spiritual and emotional neglect. Certain leaders who created a culture of fear, intimidation and bullying were not only tolerated, but promoted within the organization. If leaders get the results leadership wants to see, they got promoted, regardless of their competency to care for people. I have many, many friends who had to go to therapy and/or leave the organization to find healing. - Results are everything. Results are defined by church attendance. It is all about the numbers. The pace can be crushing, it can cost you spiritual health and marital wellness, but if the numbers are growing then God must be in it! - There seems to be a culture of retaliation at the highest levels. Unwanted feedback will be dealt with harshly. - In my opinion, there is a deep rooted fear of cultural backlash. Rather than stand for biblical truth, controversial topics are often avoided at all costs. - I believe that there are many pastors at locations who have little to no biblical competence, but as long as they have potential to be leaders (influencers) they are seen as more than equipped as Pastors. Biblical literacy was never measured during interviews and was rarely developed while on the team.

pros:
As someone who has worked in the corporate world most of my career, Life.Church is uniquely family friendly. Family takes priority and my job/role never feels threatened when that is put to the test. 

I feel well cared for as a person. My mental and physical health are genuinely encouraged. Our benefits are very generous (ie. medical, PTO, retirement, etc). We are purposefully appreciated on a consistent basis. Wins and milestones are celebrated BIG. 

I am supported as a leader. We receive constructive feedback regularly and multiple development opportunities are presented to take advantage of. Regardless of ranking, opinions and ideas matter and feedback is encouraged to be reciprocated. 

Teamwork is a reality here. We don’t compete against each other but work alongside each other toward a mission we’re all passionate about. Whether that means stepping in to cover someone’s responsibilities when they’re taking PTO or navigating an emergency/crisis, the team willingly ensures there aren’t any gaps so that person is able to fully disengage. Strengths, weaknesses, gifts and personality types are identified in a healthy way so they can best be utilized and developed. Collaboration is abundant here.
cons:
Incompetent leaders do exist in the organization that make it challenging for some to succeed, despite the incredible investment the org makes to develop leaders. Fortunately, I don’t work with any of them in my line of the org chart. 

We can be too “nice” with each other that communication can sometimes be diluted and lack accountability. This can also lead to inefficiency in processes and achieving objectives. 

Pay for most of the central office roles is below market. Without the “perks” of ministry tax incentives in these roles, there is definitely a financial sacrifice to consider before accepting one of these roles.

review_title: Be prepared to give up your whole life - inside and outside of work - to the org
pros: Global reach (if you care about that).
cons: You will slowly lose your identity as an individual, all in the name of the ministry. Be prepared to not only give your all to your job, but also your entire family spending all weekends and holidays serving at church. Eventually you'll realize that people are just coming to a feel-good experience without any opportunity to actually go deep in their faith. And you are just a cog in that system. Life.Church is really good at marketing, and their value statements are catchy. But the church has grown to a point that they don't really even live those values anymore. Sure, at first there's the honeymoon phase. But in the end, you realize that being on staff there is pretty much like being in a cult. You are controlled by a charismatic leader that forces you to give your whole life to the org, you are required to give away 10% of your below-market paycheck back to the leader (who is a multi-millionaire), and if you speak out against them you will be shunned and silenced.

pros: Great benefits, lots of development opportunities, room for advancement, amazing coworkers and volunteers
cons: Pace is incredibly fast and can make you burnout very quickly. Definitely an achievement culture, the harder you work, the more opportunities you’ll get. If you slow down because you’re struggling, you get sidelined or left behind. Work/life balance is non-existent at times. It’s a struggle to get leadership to understand that going fast isn’t always the best option when it’s hurting the people doing the work. On the YouVersion team specifically, you must compete for resources and beg for headcount/new hires. Tools that are required to do your role effectively are not provided, or you have to build them yourselves. You are held accountable for issues that happen because your team doesn’t have the capacity/bandwidth to take on more. Some teams are over resourced, while others are barely able to keep their heads above water. I have seen many of my friends crying and overwhelmed because they feel they can’t keep up, or just aren’t doing enough.

After receiving a yearly review of just shy of an exceeds expectations for my role, 3 weeks later I was made aware that my leaders had been in discussion for “months” to remove me from my role and demote me to something else with no prior conversations. Words in the meeting like, “this is going to be surprising” and “I know I just dropped a bomb in your families lap” would have never been allowed when we first were hired. Sadly it appears to be more common place at Life.Church as I have talked with current and former employees that have experienced the same thing. I believe leadership is getting tired of dealing with the problems of ministry at the scale that Life.Church is now at. Couple this with many tenured people leaving or being let go, the internal culture of consistency is beginning to break away and heavy handed leadership of “my way or the highway” has begun to take hold. I wish nothing but good things for LC, but I am afraid that if some internal structural change doesn’t occur then in the not too distance future, we will be listening to the podcast, “The Rise and Fall of Life.Church: how the largest church crumbled from the inside.”

review_title: Almost One Year Out and Still Processing- My Story
job_title: Central Team Leader in Edmond, OK
pros: I joined the LC team in March of 2019 as a team member on their previous HR team. The role I was in was an HR Partner and I quickly progressed while on staff into the role I had when I left the team last summer as a CTL of Benefits, which became a new team shortly after I started separate from HR that I was given to create and lead. I felt my hard work and passion for the team members on staff was recognized, not by my immediate leader but by the rest of the organization. The benefits package was designed to pour into the team and their families in a way ministry salaries do not, while also recognizing the locations across the country. I had a unique opportunity of being able to talk to our team members and their families every day and that was extremely life giving. My role itself included building and leading the team, strategically redesigning the benefits package, educating team members on changes and how to best use their benefits, walking through Covid and everything that came with that to keep our church open and free resources flowing, births, miscarriages, deaths of team members, terminations and retirements, new hires coming on, traveling to almost every LC location in 8 months to set up Direct Primary Care, speaking at Family Reunion on retirement, and even addressing our organization on a mandatory live broadcast about the open enrollment changes coming with my CGL and DLT. Everything about that role was a dream come true. The perfect job where I pictured myself never leaving. I loved leading. I loved the way God used me to give back and felt closer to Him while on staff than I had ever felt. I felt I was in exactly the right place. There are some amazing leaders at Life.Church. You will grow faster than ever before. You will be met with challenges daily and overcome them in ways you never thought possible. Your team becomes your family and your prayer warriors. There are so many people working for LC all over the country that you will be in awe of how God is using them.
cons: Within a few weeks on staff while in the HR role my leader was fired due to to poor leadership, decisions or lack thereof, and frequent absence. I took it in stride and saw the opportunity to help fill a gap, which put me under new leadership that was extremely toxic and what I could see the reason for the previous leader stepping off the team. I believe there were at least 7-9 terminations on the Staff Operations Group in the short span I was on staff due to leader I had. I was treated as a threat my entire time on staff, which made my working relationship with my leader difficult. In the beginning, I thought that this was something that no one saw and with how much I cared about Life.Church and the employees I knew I had to say something even if it ended in termination. What I unfortunately realized is that everyone knew and accepted it. I was told on several occasions that peers of this leader and even higher were aware of how toxic the environment was. I was advised to challenge this leadership and was met with gaslighting and even worse. This type of leadership where someone is looking for ways to get rid of you and tells you that or the most common saying in my one on ones which was "I have enough to get rid of you, if I wanted to..." caused everything to spin out. I became unhealthy and poured even more of myself into my work as a mom of toddlers, not my family. My marriage was not in the best shape when I came onto the team but that became the target for my leader to attack, my achilleas heal. I would go into one on ones trying desperately to seek wisdom or show what we were working on as a team and was met with questions about my personal life and assumptions that were not accurate. I often left believing the narrative I was told about my own personal life. When my ex-husband filed for divorce he was interviewed by my leader and a DLT member without my knowledge or consent. I was told directly after that interview that they would allow me to stay on staff as an exception, while rumors went wild with the personal information leaked by my leader. A few weeks later I put my notice in with DLT and made it very clear why I could not work under that leadership. It will go down as one of the most heartbreaking conversations of my life with the person I loved and respected the most while on the team and one of the hardest things I have had to do. I am now almost a year out and I am still hearing rumors of what people believe happened or were told about my exit by leadership. I loved my church before I came on staff, and I love my church now. I have a hard time walking back into the physical location of church and separating the immense hurt. I am flooded with memories both beautiful ones of lives changed and feeling the Holy Spirit so clearly moving in a room to memories of sitting at my leader's desk where I would leave in tears and anxiety attacks. The people that I was told loved me "unconditionally" no longer speak to me. I believe in restoration and know that this was a unique situation, but how unique is it for this leader.

job_title: Central Team Leader in Edmond, OK
pros:
I've been here over 10 years and fall more in love with this place every day. I'm a more faith-filled follower of Christ, better spouse and parent, stronger leader, and more generous person overall because of the impact working here has had on my life. Here are 3 areas in particular that stand out:

1. Mission: I've never been part of a place where every single person on the team is fully committed to our mission of leading people to become fully devoted followers of Christ. There's something incredibly special when the entire staff is running in the same direction, aligned in their values, and full of trust for each other.

2. Impact: I've never been part of a place that has such a far-reaching, global, local, and personal impact in people's lives. It's incredibly humbling and fulfilling to get to be part of.

3. Culture: I've never been part of a place that has such a high emphasis on trust, transparency, feedback, accountability, personal and family health, and leadership development opportunities. We work hard, have so much fun in the process, and experience tremendous growth every day.
cons:
The cons I tend to see people mention most here are 1) work-life balance and 2) pay. Here's why I don't have any concerns about either one:

Work-life balance: This is really up to you! Let me explain: There is so much trust given in how we manage our schedules and workload, so each person really has to have the personal discipline to do that well instead of relying on the organization to do it for you. If you're someone who hasn't yet established healthy work-life rhythms, you're going to struggle no matter where no work. But if you're someone who has learned to manage your time and energy well, this is such a freeing, trusting place to work. My team is so great about working hard when we work, being fully present with family when we're home, and holding each other accountable to taking great time off to recharge. (For instance, we'll lovingly get onto each other if we ever see someone checking emails on vacation!) This is a place that highly emphasizes your personal health and your family—but it takes you playing your part in that too.

Pay: Yes, you could get more if you worked somewhere else. If your top career goal is to make money, this isn't the place for you. But if your top goal is to use your skills and gifts to lead people to Christ, I can't think of anywhere better to fulfill that calling every day. I personally find the pay very fair and more than enough for my family to live comfortably. And when I add in the crazy generous benefits package (especially the 401k matching!), the healthy work culture, the development opportunities, etc., it's a no-brainer. It's an honor to me to get to live out my calling here AND receive such a high level of care through not just salary, but benefits, leadership, etc. For me, it's all a matter of perspective and priorities.

I lived through frequent anxiety and/or depression (conditions I’d never experienced prior to this job), and I consistently dreaded going to work.

As others here have said, this job starts out wonderful--the opportunity to work for your beloved church home feels like a dream come true. Our mission is more than just words on a wall - we truly exist and focus solely on projects and goals that lead people to become fully devoted followers of Christ.

Our culture is intentional, not accidental. We live and breathe by our aligning organizational values, which drive and guide our high-performing teams. 

Our staff is valued. We are a team full of leaders who have other leaders investing in us, our families, and our development. Additionally, our compensation and benefits are competitive, with year-end review salary increases based on performance. We also highly value our families, knowing they are our #1 ministries God calls us to. 

Our teams have fun. We really do enjoy what we do, while doing it with people we enjoy being around. As a high-performance organization, we make sure to let loose and have fun!
cons: The pace is so fast that it's not the right fit for everyone. If you do not thrive in flexible, dynamic, and highly-driven staff teams, this would not be the right fit for you. To go the distance on this team, you must be well-centered in who you are.

pros: I can't think of any greater cause worth giving my life to than reaching people who do not know Christ.  God has positioned LifeChurch.tv in such a way that we can be very successful in doing just that.  I love seeing lives changed and people come alive as they experience life as God intended it to be.  We also have a blast!  It is a challenging work environment where you will grow and develop in ways you never imagined possible, but it is all worth it!  LifeChurch.tv leadership is authentic and passionate.  Wouldn't want to work anywhere else!
cons: The work environment is intense.  There are high expectations combined with a culture of constant feedback.  If you don't like a fast paced, development focused, high accountability work environment that is focused on producing results ... LifeChurch.tv is probably not a good fit.

review_title: This culture is one full of nothing but growth, love, and genuine care about people.
pros: I absolutely love the genuine relationships you create, the opportunities to not only use your God-given gifts but the opportunities to grow in them as well, and all of the benefits that come with working here. They don't just encourage being a good employee, they encourage being a good person as well as giving you opportunities and resources to do that.
cons: This is not so much a con but more of a reality of working here. Because you work at a church, you automatically assume the role of a leader and are held to high standards in every aspect of your life professionally, relationally, financially, physically, mentally, and 100% spiritually. Every single person on staff can admit that at times it can be difficult, but we also see that our reactions to difficult times are part of bringing glory to God.

review_title: What You See is What You Get.
job_title: Associate LGLM Pastor in Stillwater, OK
pros:
1. The Culture here is hands-down the best I've been apart of ever.
2. The people here are the best of best I've worked with within our generation.
3. The benefits are irrationally generous. 
4. The systems are seamless. 
5. Last and containing the most - the vision, mission, and call is the most important in the world.
cons:
1. The learning curve is the steepest I've ever attempted to climb.
2. The pace is ridiculous. There are only two speeds here GO and GO FASTER.
3. As with all ministry, the work is incredibly important and has eternal weight. Be prepared for many long nights.

pros:
At Life.Church you are contunually growing in your capacity.  We're so passionate about finding the right place for the right people that you have space to learn new things and discover talents you maybe didn't know you had.  All they while you're continuing to hone those abilities and apply them to a mission everyone is so passionate about.
You are challenged, offered feedback, and allowed to develop as a leader and a contributor to the global Church.
You work with people that become like family because all are devoted to the same cause of leading others to become fully devoted followers of Christ.
Family is so important and Life.Church recognizes and honors that.  While we put in long hours at times, we understand that a healthy home life is necessary to your health and the mission to which we are all called.
Life.Church invests in its staff, unlike any other organization I've ever been a part of.  
If you're here, you will be challenged to grow and to become better in all areas of your life.  We sharpen each other and care for each other.
cons: In ministry, you cannot and should not expect financial incentives

review_title: Making a Huge Difference in the World and in Me
pros:
This is by far the best place I have ever worked, and I have enjoyed working with some great organizations earlier in my career.  It is rare to work at a place that is making a significant difference all around the world and at the same time making a significant difference in you.  This is that place.  Life.Church is constantly growing and reaching more people around the world literally every day, while at the same time, it is pushing me to constantly grow.  

The mission here is clear and massive.   Everyone's passion to reach the mission is tangible and contagious.  The culture of development is strong for all aspects of my life.  Since my time on staff, my leadership is sharper; my finances are stronger; my faith is deeper; and my heart is larger for people and for the church.  This is definitely not a job for me, it is my calling.  I absolutely love it!
cons: If you are uncomfortable with high feedback, high transparency, a strong growth mindset and fast pace then this would not be the place for you.

job_title: LifeKIDS Coordinator in Broken Arrow, OK
pros: Life.Church is not only a place where you can live out your calling to lead people to become fully devoted followers of Christ, but it is an amazing organization to work for. You are truly cared for as a person, and there are so many opportunities to grow and develop as a person and in your leadership. I love the people I work with - we have so much fun together!
cons: To be successful at Life.Church, you must be humble, flexible, resilient, self aware, teachable. You also must have amazing work ethic, be culturally relevant, and have a sense of humor. If this doesn't describe you at your core being, then Life.Church is not for you. I have worked at Life.Church for a year and a half and I honestly don't have anything bad to say. I love what I get to do, but I will say that I have worked harder and grown more in the last year and a half than I have my whole working career prior. Life.Church stretches you, refines you, and pushes you to be better. That's not a con, unless you hate to be uncomfortable, and then maybe it is.

review_title: Life-Giving Job & Atmosphere, But Also Challenging
pros: So many pro's! Life.Church is the only workplace I've experience where my boss genuinely cares for me and my physical, mental, and spiritual well-being. It's not only about my job performance. Everything I get to do everyday is connected to a calling higher than any of us can even understand. It is a responsibility and an honor to be trusted to walk in that. As if that isn't enough, benefits are INSANELY good. 401k contribution is next level. You also receive consistent development in all areas from your boss and the organization as a whole.
cons:
• This isn't necessarily a con, but something for people interested in working at Life.Church to be aware of. Working at Life.Church is hard. You are stretched and pushed way past the capacity you think you have. But you also will grow more than you ever have before!
• Be aware of work/life balance. It is easy to work work work when you love what you do, but in order to last (and even thrive) at Life.Church, you need to be aware of that balance, and invite your leader into that process. They are for you, not against you.

pros:
Strong feeling that my efforts have eternal significance!
I know that I am doing exactly what I am called to do in this season of my life!
I get to come to work with my friends every day.
Challenging role and responsibilities. 
Really strong development and feedback culture.
Inspiring, trustworthy leadership who, I truly feel, want the best for me personally and in my role.
Top Notch benefits for my family.
Quarterly Wellness reimbursement.
Innovation is valued and encouraged.
The Central offices are located in Edmond, OK, which is a really wonderful place to live and raise a family.
cons:
The team overall is pretty lean, so I have had plenty of times when I felt overwhelmed and that I had more on my plate than I could possibly get done. 
No mountains, no beach.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Edmond, OK
pros:
- Mission of YouVersion is to get the Bible to the whole world.  Everyone on the team loves the mission and it's great for us to all be on the same page about what is important and what we are trying to achieve
- Flexible hours when personal needs arise
- Digital release schedule allows some wiggle room on deadlines.  This means higher quality releases.  I came from a packaged goods company previously where deadlines were very firm so tons of overtime was needed to make the deadline.
- So much personal development!  The church we are working for cares a lot about every person.  The training and guidance we receive is amazing.  We are regularly trained in how to be an effective leader.
- Always on the cutting-edge of tech.  Our team size allows us to stay up to date with tech that Google and Apple are pioneering.  There is relatively little legacy code, and we are always pushing the boundaries of the best trends in software.
- Best co-workers ever.  Every one of them is awesome.
cons: - Compensation isn't the best

pros: Working at LC is not a job it’s a calling! LC has some of the best leadership on the planet and they invest in every employees leadership. It is a great workplace environment where everyone feels valued and absolute trust is extended. The annual review process is based on goals you set and there is frequent communication with your team leaders on those goals so you always know where you stand. The benefits package is second to none and LC really takes care of their people. No matter what your gifts and talents or personality you get to see lives changed every day and your work has an eternal implication.
cons: Working at LC can be very fast-paced and challenging at times. The mission is so critical and growth is not optional, it’s expected. Expect a high-level of feedback and to be asked to lead through situations you’ve never led through. You can expect to fail and learn from those failures in a fast paced kingdom focused environment.

review_title: Working at LifeChurch has been the best experience of my life.
job_title: Campus Administrator in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: There are so many pros to this job.  My co-workers are truly another family to me.  For the first time in my life, I love coming to work each and every day.  I miss this place when I'm not here.  The leadership is phenomenal throughout the line.  Everyone encourages and provides feedback for constant growth.  Self discovery and personal growth are key to this job and LifeChurch makes it so easy to better myself as a person, employee, Christian, friend, and mom.
cons: This is something different from anything I have ever done before.  It took a lot of learning and patience.  The tough days are tough, but the good days out weigh that for sure.  It is definitely a sink or swim culture, so you have to push yourself harder than ever before.

review_title: I would refer a friend any day to come work at Life.Church!
job_title: Recruitment Campus Coordinator in Edmond, OK
pros: First of all, I love getting to work at Life.Church because I get to use my gifts to grow heaven! Also, the team as a whole is so willing to help each other out. We all want each other to win in their roles so I always feel supported not only by my leaders but the team at large. With that being said, there is a lot of development that happens around here. That takes some getting use to, but you have to know it's all out of love. Plus, if you're real with yourself, you wouldn't want to stay at a workplace who doesn't care about you developing and getting better!
cons: We are very fast paced here at Life.Church. Sometimes we can move so quickly that we don't take time to pause and celebrate the wins. It's a hard balance because we have to keep moving forward but we never want to miss what's happening all around us.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: LifeChurch.tv has a great corporate culture. With core values like fun, generosity, risk-taking, etc., it's a great place to work. Team and personal development are both very important at LifeChurch.tv. The leadership invests a lot of time and effort in helping every employee reach their full potential. The benefits are very good. LifeChurch.tv offers extra benefits, like cell phone reimbursement, wellness reimbursement, etc.
cons: I wouldn't consider these as "cons" but more as challenges. The culture is very driven and the expectations are high. Staff members are expected to keep up or speak up. It's also a very high feedback culture, which is a big plus, but it can be difficult for new employees who are not yet accustomed to it. Roll with the punches, keep the lines of communication open and push through the learning curve. It's worth it!

review_title: Best Organization to work with that has a Mission and Purpose
pros: Mission, Purpose, Development, Sacrifice, Generosity, Values, Vision, Benefits are outstanding, Family Oriented, Strong Work Ethic, Yearly Reviews to help you learn and grow.
cons: There are not many cons to be called into ministry.  It is a sacrifice but it is worth it!

review_title: The healthiest work culture I've ever been apart of.
pros: I've worked in ministry for the last 8 years and I have had the privilege to be apart of a number of churches both small and large. Life.Church has been the healthiest church I've been apart of yet. From the top down there is accountability and balance to every person in leadership. Its a place where feedback is not only welcomed but encouraged and that goes for anyone in any position. The leadership truly cares about every individual on staff and that shows through the generous salary/benefits and the personal/spiritual investment they make into you as a  leader. Due to my experiences, I came in as a skeptic, looking for at least one red flag to be discovered about the leadership and structure but over a year on staff and I have nothing but positive things to say. I'm grateful to be apart of this organization and what God is doing through our church.
cons: It can be a very fast-paced culture, things move and happen quickly and if you aren't used to that then it could a hard adjustment.

review_title: My experience has been one of great personal, professional and spiritual growth.
pros: One of the best things about working here is the opportunity to increase your self awareness and grow as a person. Family is important and valued at LifeChurch.tv. My life isn't compartmentalized anymore. There isn't a work life and a home life. It is all melded into one. I am who I am at work and at home and the people I work with are just as much family as my family is. One group working toward a common goal.
cons: You have to be strong spiritually to withstand the spiritual attacks. You WILL get pushed out of your comfort zone and you WILL have to grow and develop to stay on staff. It is lean here. One person typically does the work load of a person and a half to two people.

review_title: Leading People to Become Fully Devoted Followers of Christ
pros: It's incredible to contribute to such a meaningful and important mission--we lead people to become fully devoted followers of Christ! Even in behind the scenes, technical, or specialized roles we are connected to the constant miracle of life change. The leadership demonstrates such integrity and humility. The culture encourages personal growth. The people on my team are my extended family. I have worked here for 11 years and wouldn't trade my time here for anything.
cons: If you are not committed to leading people to follow Christ with excellence and integrity, you will not like this environment. Our team is hard-core committed to improvement and innovation. If you have the ambition to make a name for yourself, don't bother applying. You will not last here. This mission isn't about personal accomplishments and accolades on earth. While there are opportunities for advancement and growth, don't consider a role as getting your foot in the door or a springboard to other things. These are only cons if you are not a fit for our fast-paced Jesus-first environment.

pros:
When people ask me what I do and how I like it, my answer has been "I can't imagine working anywhere else" for the past couple years. Success here isn't measured by how far you rise and how fast, it's measured by how the whole team moves the mission forward. Pros:
-The best mission you could ask for
-Great management
-Dedication to the why, not the how
-Excellent benefits (401k, medical, time off, on-site childcare)
-High-quality co-workers--you will like the people you work with
-An absolute library of training material and learning opportunities for you to own your own development
cons:
-If you're always looking for your next step up the ladder, this place won't fit you. 
-If a high salary is a must, this place won't fit you (but you will get free tools, training, and resources to maximize what you earn).
-If you're not willing to spend time outside of work volunteering, this place won't fit you.
-If you need constant supervision, this place won't fit you. We extend a lot of trust to the people who work here.

review_title: Living out my calling. Fulfilling my purpose.
job_title: Central Team Leader in Edmond, OK
pros:
Healthy organizational structure that begins at the top with clear vision, strong leadership values and passion for our mission. Strong culture for developing high-capacity, innovative, servant leaders that are mission focused. Family comes first above all else. Marriages are nurtured, valued and guarded. Life.Church is an innovative environment with a focus on efficiency and effectiveness and keeping things simple. There is little to no red tape and this allows for focused momentum in all areas. Trust is freely given. Accountability is expected.  Feedback is what we eat for breakfast. You will thrive at Life.Church if you are mission focused, willing to sacrifice and approach leadership with humility. 

 Leadership cares deeply for every team member. Individual opinion matters and is always heard. Over time you will reach a point of deep desire to "guard the house".
cons: This is not your typical place to work. The meek need not apply. You can't go it alone. We are stronger together. If you like to work in isolation, this is not the place for you.

pros:
- Everyone who works here is passionate and driven to help the organization succeed. 
- Management is top-notch and goes over-the-top to take care of everyone who works here. 
- Each department from the top down is mission-focused and does an amazing job in their respective areas. 
- Benefits are better than that offered by most other companies out there
- Motivating and inspiring environment that always re-energizes me every day
cons: The environment may not be for everyone. Everyone working here has a passion and drive to help the overall mission and vision of the organization, and if you aren't fully committed, you will likely not succeed.

job_title: Content Partnerships Coordinator in Edmond, OK
pros: Lifechurch.tv has an excellent mission and is committed to consistently driving all momentum to achieve that mission. It's an honor to serve on this team, and I'm proud of the work we get to do.
cons: Anything valuable takes sacrifice. There have been lots of sacrifices I've made in order to stay committed to the organization, and sometimes at the expense of my family who lives far away.

review_title: At Life.Church behind the scenes is even better then the public view.
pros:
Best place I have ever worked and I’ve worked for a lot of companies even great ones. 

The mission is clear and meaningful. It isn’t something that is just stated because it sounds nice. Everyone works together to accomplish that mission and enjoy working together to get there. 

It is evident that the leaders care about people. They believe in the health and well being of their employees. It is just as important as the mission and support is offers in so many ways.
cons:
Because of the drive and mission it is a fast paced organization. If you do not pace yourself and take care of yourself you can find that you burn out easily. Leadership will help you but you have to be willing and self aware to take the steps. 

Pay isn’t as high as other churches, but trust me, it’s worth it. You are taken care of and pay is good, especially as you stay with the organization.

job_title: Host Team Pastor in Wellington, FL
pros: LifeChurch.tv has an incredible passion for developing people to become better. I absolutely love the fact that there is always something more to accomplish, always a better way to do something. There is always something new to dream about and make a reality. I have full confidence that the organization cares more about me as an individual than about what I can do for them, and that attitude carries into everything I do. It's the best organization I've ever worked for.
cons: The staff is lean on purpose. It requires people to collaborate together, which is great. What can be challenging is when you add to that high expectations of excellence and achievement, as well as the pressure of other people depending on that achievement. You NEED to develop other people and volunteers around you - this is not the organization for a lone wolf.

review_title: Certainly not for me and lots of others
pros: I enjoyed what I did at the time. Work
cons:
The likelihood of you advancing is not very there.
Compensation is horrible. Very hard to support a family on the offered salary and felt like salary raises were contingent on a very hard annual review. Honestly, there were months that it was hard to make ends meet. Spouse most assuredly needs to work.
They preach about everyone being a family and being part of a ministry, but at the same time, it is also very much a business to them. Management will certainly bring up the business aspect anytime they feel you are doing something wrong and will use that in your reviews. But it's all for the ministry! See how confusing this is?

pros: Loose, open environment that offers flexibility while keeping high expectations on you work.  This high feedback environment provides ample opportunity to be more self-aware and allows for further development of your current skills and development of new skills.  Working at the Central offices provides more of a for-profit organizational structure, but still offers that support that your would expect from a church.  Working here allows me to use my skills and professional back ground while assisting in furthering the Kingdom of God.
cons: Leadership talks about raising up young leaders, while this is true at the campuses, it is not as true at Central.  This may be caused by long working tenures of those in leadership positions.  If coming from the professional, for-profit world, be willing to take a pay cut, after all, this is still a Church.

review_title: LifeChurch.tv is a place that has truly changed my life and a placed I am honored to serve by being on staff!
job_title: Project Leader in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: There are so many great things! The freedom to innovate, the ability to hang out with staff and collaborate, the opportunity to see lives changed on a regular basis...I could go on for ages. It's so varied and fast paced but the amount of fun we have doing it and the lives we see changed is so worth it.
cons: I would say that some challenges would be balancing personal life and being able to be "off." Our pace can be brutal for families so it's just very important to have time to take off, time to leave work at work and be supported in those decisions by your team. It's all about balance.

pros:
It has been incredible to see just how healthy everything is here at Life.Church, and it plays a huge part in why the church is seeing such great growth and making a huge impact. Benefits are amazing with low premiums and a great 401k plan, plus a huge chunk of vacation time which is so needed in the ministry world.

Coming to work is fun, and the people I work with care about me personally. The church does, too. They've made and continue to make investments into me personally and spiritually, even providing a yearly personal/leadership development budget and a quarterly fitness bonus.
cons:
It's a high feedback culture, and that means that you really have to stay humble and teachable otherwise it will be tough for you to work here.

You have to be okay with a high pace and long days. Some campuses have 7 services on Sundays, which can be exhausting. Thankfully, there is a rotation so you don't have to be at every service every Sunday.

review_title: Great place to work if you mesh with the corporate culture
pros: Great mission, great coworkers, relatively minimal politics relative to most jobs, great HR hiring/on-boarding/annual review processes, great benefits package, high-trust/high-feedback environment, great sense of camaraderie and humor in the workplace.
cons: It's a lean organization, so be prepared to put in a LOT of extra hours. Management tries to encourage time off and work-life balance, but since it's a calling and not a career for most folks, people tend to burn the candle at both ends.

pros: Our mission gives our teams unique passion and shared purpose. It's a huge benefit to show up at work and know that what you're doing is making a difference. I've also never worked somewhere that has cared for and invested in me more than I have here. The culture is healthier than any others I've experienced or been close to personally.
cons: You pretty much can't succeed on staff if you're not committed to growth and development. It can get a little personal and painful at times, so you have to be open to that. But I can say those moments were never outside of a context of caring for me, and I've grown more here than I even thought I was capable of. Also, if you're not into team-building activities, you might have some unenjoyable moments. Overall, if you're a clock-in, keep-your-head-down, clock-out kind of worker it might not be your favorite environment.

pros: All-in calling for the mission to lead people to Christ. No matter the method, the mission and heart of the organization is the same. Great development culture - you have the opportunity to be better every year, you just have to do it. Wonderful support of team members - benefits, time off, prayer, community/family.
cons: This is not a place to work if you just want to "get by" or "do the work." With the high feedback culture, you will receive input about WHO are you and HOW you lead, not just WHAT you do. That can be uncomfortable for some people. You will work a lot, so if you're not called to be here the hours can be a struggle. You will sacrifice a large salary, but you will make a life-long difference.

job_title: LifeGroup & Missions Project Leader in Jenks, OK
pros: Love the flexible work environment, lends very well to creating balance between work and family. Self-development is highly encouraged. The Pace is fast and you always feel challenged. Incredible leadership over the church as a whole, very organized, highly value excellence. Do a great job of building up leaders and encouraging us to expand our leadership.
cons:
The only downside our family has experienced is just with having a spouse with an opposite schedule can occasionally make it difficult to find family time as a whole or getting creative with child care for one time events and such but outside of that I really can't come up with any true "downsides".

The only advice I can offer is if you are not highly driven and fast-paced, this may not be the work environment for you. We run on two speeds: Chaos and Insane.

review_title: Beyond what I could have thought or imagined!
job_title: Central Team Leader in Edmond, OK
pros: It is unbelievable how God has shaped my journey at Life.Church.  I entered the team 11 years ago knowing I was called to ministry, but I lacked the detail of in what function.  That first role engaged some skills that I brought to the table, but over the years the development culture and the amazing leaders that have surrounded me have allowed me to grow and step into the calling God has for my life.  At this point, I feel as though I am in the center of His will and would be honored and humbled to continue serving Him in my current role for the remainder of my career.
cons: I don't have cons because of how much I love my job.  Similar to other reviews on Glassdoor, there is a commitment to sacrifice as it relates to compensation that is a part of working at Life.Church.  I support that vision.

review_title: Couldn't have asked for a better place to work.
pros: Personal Development is huge, high feedback culture, people here are mission driven, there is a high excellence culture, you are given every opportunity to succeed, everyone leads with trust. The list goes on and on, culture is amazing. The benefits are extremely competitive, especially the health, dental, vision, 401(k) matching, phone plan, and childcare (on premises at central offices!)
cons:
Sometimes the soft drink dispenser is occasionally out of carbonation...and that's a serious problem. s/ 
Seriously, expect to work harder than you ever have before, not because someone is breathing down you neck and forcing you to, but because you WANT to! Also, you will be pushed to be the best that you can be ALL THE TIME (that's almost never an easy road). (These probably should have been in the Pros section)

review_title: The best and most fulfilling place I’ve ever worked.
pros: The mission of Life.Church is what drew me to apply and the last 3 years have been the most fulfilling and inspiring years of my life. I have loved being a part of seeing kids and families grow closer to God and to each other. The relationships I have built with other staff members, my volunteer team, and our attenders fill my tank each week. If you are someone who loves to work hard, love people in the middle of the mess, and see lives changed every week, you would love being a part of the mission of Life.Church!
cons: This is not a con, but we are a high feedback culture that places value on work ethic and flexibility. If you are not motivated and can’t see yourself pouring your blood, sweat, and tears (literally) into loving people and doing anything short of sin to reach people for Christ, Life.Church is not your best fit.

review_title: It's not just a job, it's so much more!
pros: Working for Lifechurch has been the best decision of my life! I GET to be passionate about what I do and I GET to be a part of something so much bigger than myself.  I get to use the talents that God has placed inside of me even though I work more behind the scenes.  Your development matters at Lifechurch and there is plenty of opportunities for you to learn and grow.
cons: Things move fast and furious around here.  Change comes often so if you're not flexible you will be miserable.   Spiritual attacks are real and happen. Once you sign onto work at LC you have this huge target on you.

pros: Ministering to people. Knowing I was doing Kingdom work! Benefits were good! Met a lot of new, amazing people!
cons: They are turning the church more into a business. Numbers were more important than people. High demands. Expectations were rediculous!Little time with your family. Work 5-6 days a week, depending on campus. High turnover. People were placed into positions they were not qualified. And, don't expect to stay at a campus for more than 3 years. You are expected to grow and move up the ranks, even if you didn't feel called.

pros: Cheesy title I know. Living the dream is a phrase I use all the time just in life. I believe God has equipped me to build His Kingdom and strengthen the Church and be a light for folks and I know I could be doing that anywhere. And I thank God every day that Life.Church is where I am. My boss is amazing. I have real friends. The vision and message is clear. I feel cared about not just because of how I'm treated by peers and leadership, but because of the benefits package, development opportunities, and review structure. This is a fantastic place to work. I'm unapologetically biased.
cons: I've had different bosses in my time here. Some have not been the type of leader I serve under today. Leadership styles aren't always consistent across locations and departments, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.

job_title: Associate Operations Pastor in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Life.Church has a special place in my heart. The ways I was poured into was unlike anywhere I have ever experienced. The constant intentionality, care, love, integrity, and opportunity for growth made you feel needed and known and was such an incredible place to be a part of.
cons: There is definitely a lack of diversity organization-wide.

review_title: I can't believe I get to do this!
pros: Not only is this the greatest mission in the world (to lead people to become fully devoted followers of Christ), this is the best place to work. You are cared about as a person, not just an employee.  The development you get is top-notch. Leaders from all over the organization pour into you and invest in you as though you're their responsibility. You work hard, but it's totally worth it.
cons: There are many seasons that demand a lot of overtime.  It's manageable and not inconsistent with overtime requirements of other jobs, but it's up to the individual to maintain a healthy perspective.

pros:
The mission of Life.Church has remained the same throughout the years and keeps the entire staff focused. However, the way we go about achieving that mission has changed with the times to foster innovation and risk-taking ideas.

We also have a culture of development - both professional and personal. We all strive to improve and bring our best every day. pros: Energetic work environment, plenty of opportunities to meet and work with people, always the top-tier equipment at your disposal, beautiful facilities, incredible benefits
cons:
Life.Church was an amazing company to work for... when I started 10 years ago. From my honest experience over the years, the bigger the church got, the less you were able to be a pastor, and the more you were just an employee expected to meet expectations and hit your metrics. The more responsibility you were handed, the more the “pastor” title was blurred. When I started at LC, I was living out a calling in my life. The church was small, the focus was on people, and everyone had the same incredible energy. God was moving through me and I truly felt like I was making a difference, but somewhere along the way, upper-leadership, on the campus level and central level, shifted away from the people of the church and instead focused on the excellence of the experience and the numbers. They’d never admit that, but it’s 100% true. I didn’t even notice this shift until I was in a high level leadership role. I took an honest look at the church and came to this realization. When I tried focusing on the people of the church and listening to what my employees, my team’s volunteers, and our attenders needed, I didn’t get any encouragement from my management, and instead my ideas got shut down by higher-ups for more “numbers-driven” goals. This happened more than once, publicly (in front of other pastors in my role) and privately (in one-on-one conversations with my management). Eventually it got to a point where my job was no longer being a pastor, and instead my job was managing my employees as well as my team’s unpaid volunteer leaders while also being delegated several of my boss’ responsibilities, which never included being able to step up and simply pastor people. The burnout began to sink in, because I was no longer doing what I was called to. I lost all passion for the church and my role, and I knew it was time to leave. LC took care of me during my transition out, but to my surprise, I never heard from anyone once I left. All of my so-called “friends and family” I met and grew close to while there never reached out to me. Even after reaching out a couple times to old coworkers asking to get lunch or coffee, I was blown off. There was one time when an old coworker agreed to hang out and they literally didn’t show up and I didn’t hear from them. Pity. Unfortunately, I am now looking for a different church and I don’t recommend people apply for a job at LC. It used to be a fantastic company to work for. But unfortunately it no longer is. 

Some other cons are no work/life balance. If you work on a campus, you’re underpaid and overworked with one day off a week. Starting entry level salaries are around $30,000. You’re guaranteed to work 50+ hours a week.

pros: The best thing about working at LifeChurch.tv is that I really feel like I am helping to make a difference in people's lives. If I need to take off for sick kids, or if I'm sick, there are lots of options available to me. I can choose to work from home (my computer is set up to do that from DAY 1!). I can use my leave. I can adjust my hours to make up the time. Or any combination thereof.

LifeChurch.tv tends to wait to hire additional people until one person is carrying the load of at least 2 full-time people. If you don't have a good rapport with your manager, or if you are afraid that if you communicate your stress to your manager he/she will think you can't handle the job, you can easily get discouraged and overwhelmed. We use the Meyer's Briggs personality test, and if you have a manager that is a hard "TJ", it's very difficult for "FP" types to feel like they are cared about or heard.

Another con for the area where I work is a lack of training or education of the processes to the entire organization. Many of the online training courses are out-of-date, but no one has time to update them. It takes a back seat to immediate pressures.We need one place to go for current policies - all policies - not just the ones for a particular area.  And they need to be kept current as practices change. It can just be very confusing for those trying to adhere to them.  Also, new hires have it rough. Desk supplies are available, but not readily provided. They are  handed a laptop (which is cool!) but then basically left to search for the basic necessities like pen, paper, staplers and sticky notes.
